Award.AwardTitle: Numerical solution of the chemical master equation in cell biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The number of computations needed to solve the chemical master equation tends to explode because of the high number of potential states of the system and this fact motivates the need to develop sophisticated computational techniques to address this so-called "curse of dimensionality." This project seeks to address the problem using a combination of techniques such as model reduction techniques, efficient embedded techniques for the reduced problem, and inexact or relaxed function evaluations in the integration schemes.

The chemical master equation arises when mathematical modeling is used to represent the biochemical reactions that regulate the metabolism within the cells. Models of cellular processes allow experimentalists to avoid costly trial-and-error laboratory experiments in live cells . This sort of modeling poses a challenging problem because some key regulatory molecules are so small in number that the cellular processes associated with them seem random or stochastic and cells can change through a myriad of pathways that are difficult to track even on the fastest supercomputers. Thus the ability to use mathematical modeling to accurately mimic key molecules and to apply computational methods to efficiently code the simulations have important applications for fields of molecular biology and medicine because there is a significant need to accurately simulate biochemical reactions inside a cell in real time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI was awarded NSF funding to undertake research on numerical strategies to solve the chemical master equation (CME) arising in the modeling of biochemecial reactions in a cell. Our core focus was to dynamically track the subset of time-varying plausible states that the cell can have.

Intellectual Merit. The many resulting peer-reviewed papers provide the evidence that the community found the work valuable. We developed a flexible SSA-driven scheme that is multi-step and multi-stage, and capable of tracking a much reduced set of states relevant to the CME at any given time. We implemented adaptive Krylov subspace methods that improved the efficiency of the Krylov-FSP algorithm. We developed a theory to link the Krylov-FSP algorithm to the inexact matrix exponential. We also implemented a Magnus series approximation for the time-dependent CME which we found to be competitive with more traditional ODE solvers. We additionally investigated incomplete orthogonalization techniques and found that they can speed up the performance of the matrix exponential without the risk of divergence seen in linear systems and eigenvalue problems. We realized that the reduced subset of relevant states was still large and this led us to incorporate aggregation techniques to extend the applicability of our framework. We applied our SSA-driven scheme to the CME of the cancer gene p53, which solved the problem smoothly on some settings but blew up the memory requirement in others, suggesting that more research is to continue using other techniques such as tensor trains that were not in the initial proposal. 

Broader Impact. The project was a catalyst for mentoring 6 graduate students (5 PhD students and 1 master student) as well as several classroom assignments for undergraduate research experience. We ob- tained significant outcomes that were communicated to the scientific community in different formats, including journal articles in Physical Biology, Applied Mathematics and Computation, Mathematical Biosciences, Numerical Linear Algebra with Applications, The Journal of Chemical Physics, Mathematics and Computers in Simulation, and BIT Numerical Mathematics. There were peer-reviewed conference proceedings at the Bioinformatics and Biotechnology (BIOT) Symposiums in Provo, UT, in 2014 and 2015, the World Congress on Engineering and Computer Science 2016 in San Francisco, CA, the IEEE Conference on Decision and Control (CDC) 2016 in Las Vegas, NV, and the 5th International Conference on Computational and Mathematical Biomedical Engineering (CMBE2017) in Pittsburgh, PA.

Besides the conferences with peer-reviewed proceedings cited above, the PI and PhD students also gave oral or poster presentations at other conferences such as SIAM Life Sciences 2016 in Boston, MA, The Ninth q-Bio Annual Meeting 2015 in Blacksburg, VA, The Tenth q-bio Annual Meeting 2016 in Nashville, TN, the SIAM SEAS 2016 in Athens, GA, and the International Congress on Industrial and Applied Math- ematics 2015 in Beijing, China. In 2015, two PhD students attended the Ninth q-Bio Summer School in Fort Collins, CO, and the IMA Workshop on Biological Systems and Networks in Minneapolis, MN. In Summer 2016, one PhD student found an internship at Rice University in Houston, TX, and the other was selected for the one-week AMS workwhop Math Research Communitites 2016–Mathematics in Physiology and Medicine held at Snowbirds, UT. Travels at conferences gave exposure to the research, resulting in one PhD student clinching a competitive Post-Doc offer at Colorado State University immediately upon completion of his degree. The project has fostered new connections between our group and researchers in quantitative biology. We have invited researchers such as Brian Munsky from CSU, and Douglas Shep- herd from CU Denver to give talks at the Department of Mathematics of the University of Alabama.

The resulting codes are forming the basis of further development in the numerical treatment of the CME. We have published a tutorial on our inexact and improved variants of the FSP, along with other methods currently seen in the literature. This was the first comprehensive survey of its kind.
